School of Automation Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan 430070 China This paper presents a model-free dynamic optimal management strategy for a low-carbon home energy management system (HEMS) based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL). The method can ideally handle the uncertainties and dynamics of renewable energy and demand-side load. Firstly, the load model is established by a deep Q network (DQN) algorithm with the advantage of ignoring traditional forecasting steps on stochastic environments such as renewable energy generation, load demand, price, etc. Then multi-agents are established for dynamic management based on the DRL. Through “dynamic acquisition, dynamic decision” mechanism, the proposed model-free strategy achieves real-time energy management that can adaptively respond to stochastic environments. Secondly, considering the constraints of system carbon emissions and carbon trading, the proposed strategy can minimize the energy consumption cost, carbon trading cost, and user satisfaction penalties. Ultimately, the effectiveness of the proposed strategy is verified through case studies. Experimental results demonstrate that the strategy can significantly reduce the overall cost, including a 36.7% reduction in carbon trading. At the same time, user satisfaction penalties are reduced by 50.2%. Further, the agent hyperparameter could also be adjusted to capture the trade-off between cost savings and satisfaction penalties. And compared with the traditional forecast-based management strategy, it overcomes the problem of uncertainties and avoids forecasting errors to better accommodate the stochastic environment. Keywords Home energy management system Dynamic optimal management Deep reinforcement learning Low-carbon Model-free Data availability I have cited the relevant references in the manuscript for my data. 1 Introduction Residential users of distribution networks consume large amounts of energy in a flexible and uncertain manner. Building home energy management systems (HEMS) for demand-side consumers has become one of the cores to unlock the potential of customer response [1]. In the “source-load-storage” model, it realizes residential energy-saving [2]. Meanwhile, with the low-carbon policies approaching [3], a large number of end-users are potential drivers of carbon emissions [4] and have great potential to reduce carbon emissions. Therefore it is necessary for the low-carbon operation not only from the generation side [5,6], but also from the demand side, especially the low-carbon operation of HEMS. At the same time, the stochastic and volatility of distributed generation and demand put forward higher requirements for demand-side management and HEMS. From the perspective of HEMS stochastic optimization management, most traditional models are deterministic approaches [7]. For instance, [8] and [9] adopted linear programming to manage residential loads in response to real-time prices. And it was used for residential typical load curves management. The specific model of the household load was established in [10] and [11], then the model predictive control (MPC) algorithm was applied to optimize the modeled load. In addition, there is some research on home energy management based on forecast scenarios. [12] and [13] forecasted load demand through the neural network before optimizing management. The fusion of various machine learning algorithms was used for photovoltaic (PV) and load forecasting in [14]. The above models are day-ahead management. Due to the forecast error in day-ahead forecast-based optimization, some scholars have also studied different time scales, such as intra-day and real-time. Through the physical model, the intra-day priority management method based on vehicle event driving was constructed in [15]. Similarly, [16] and [17] adopted the rolling horizon management of aggregated electric vehicles and flexible loads. But it could not effectively eradicate the problems caused by forecast errors. Comprehensive analysis shows that the above models mostly depend on the forecast information such as electricity price, and load demand. However, how to avoid the errors caused by forecast algorithms and uncertainty modeling is still an unresolved problem. Recently, reinforcement learning (RL) and its derived deep reinforcement learning (DRL) have emerged to facilitate such model-free control for coordinating user flexibility with the uncertainties [18]. Based on neural networks and RL, [19] and [20] realized the HEMS dynamic energy management through the interactive update strategy between RL and the environment. However, there was only one type of load in [19], while [20] did not consider electric vehicles, etc. Through RL, the household loads including electric vehicles were dispatched with obvious optimization results in [21]. However, the electric vehicle power was not continuously adjustable, and the effects of Vehicle to Grid (V2G) and Vehicle to Home (V2H) are not considered. On the basis of this, [22] established the energy management model of electric vehicle charging by using a deep Q network (DQN). And it realized the continuous adjustment of the load. Similarly, [23] and [24] established a system economic management strategy based on DRL, but the model only aims at economic optimization. In summary, compared with the traditional forecast-based management model, models based on RL have superiority in dynamic management. However, comprehensive costs such as user comfort and system carbon emissions have not been fully considered. To sum up, there is limited research on HEMS considering low-carbon operations while ensuring energy economy and user satisfaction currently. At the same time, the existing management strategy for HEMS mostly relies on the forecast accuracy of uncertain factors. To address the aforementioned difficulties and supplement the research gap, a model-free dynamic management strategy is proposed for low-carbon home energy. Based on the DQN algorithm, the dynamic management of low-carbon optimization is realized accommodating stochastic environments aiming at the energy economy of the system, low-carbon operation and user comfort. And the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed model are verified by comparing with the traditional algorithm cases. Compared with the existing research, the major contributions of this paper can be summarized as: • We take carbon emission and carbon trading into the home energy management framework to release the massive users’ carbon emission reduction potential. The strategy can achieve the unified effect of the energy economy, low-carbon operation, and user satisfaction. • The proposed model for HEMS based on DRL does not require any distribution knowledge or system information. It can overcome the problem of uncertainties and avoid forecasting errors to better accommodate the stochastic environment such as flexible renewable energy and demand-side load. • The proposed dynamic optimal strategy can meet the respective management requirements of different users by adjusting the model parameters. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the structure of the HEMS is introduced, and the models of various types of loads and systematic carbon trading are built in detail. In Section 3, the home energy management strategy is described. In Section 4, the simulation and analysis of a case study are discussed. Then conclusions are drawn in Section 5. 2 Home energy management system 2.1 Framework of home energy management system A typical HEMS framework is shown in Fig. 1 . The system mainly consists of household loads, including, non-shiftable loads, time-shiftable loads, power-shiftable loads, and energy storage loads, and smart meter modules [25]. The smart meter externally connects with the power system to obtain the environmental conditions such as PV output, time of use price, and carbon price, while internally it connects with various household loads and house power generation units. Also, it collects the power demand of household loads and the power generation of PV. At the same time, the smart meter has the function of load triggering, and the built-in algorithm performs load switching and power control, etc. 2.2 Load model We mainly consider four types of loads, including non-shiftable loads, time-shiftable loads, power-shiftable loads, and energy storage loads [25]. According to the characteristics and requirements of the DQN algorithm [30], the action, state, as well as state transition of load are defined below. But end-users are also the underlying driver of emissions. According to the carbon emission flow model and proportional sharing principle [31], we can linearize the relationship between power flow and the accompanying virtual emission flow. (9) e t = τ p t grid + where e t is the carbon emission of loads at time t, p t grid is the power exchanged between loads and power system at time t; · + denotes taking non-negative; τ is the carbon emission characteristic factor. It characterizes linear relationships between power flow and carbon emission. (2) Carbon trading Carbon trading is a mechanism to control carbon emissions by creating legal carbon emission quotas and allowing them to carry on transactions [32]. When there is a discrepancy between carbon emissions and the carbon emission quota, HEMS, as a carbon emissions source, needs to buy or sell carbon emission quotas in the carbon trading market to maintain its operation. (10) E t trade = e t - E t ∗ where E t trade is the emission quota for entering the carbon trading market; E t ∗ is carbon emission quota. To further control the total carbon emissions, we construct a ladder-type carbon trading model. Based on the allocated carbon emission quota, the number of emission intervals is specified. And higher emission interval is related to the higher carbon trading price. When the carbon trading cost is negative, it means the HEMS emission is lower than quota. HEMS can realize profits by selling quota. 3 Energy management strategy 3.1 Objective function The objective function considers the energy economy, low-carbon operation, and user satisfaction of the HEMS. (1) Deep Q network The main features of DQN in our proposed model are as follows. • Multi-agents, including Agent ns , Agent ts , Agent ps , and Agent es are established to correspond to non-shiftable loads, time-shiftable loads, power-shiftable loads, and energy storage loads. They can manage different types of loads in a dynamic environment; • It is model-free, and it does not rely on any forecast information or distribution knowledge; • It adapts to users’ customary requirements while guaranteeing convergence and robustness. The DQN flow chart is shown in Fig. 2 [21]. The specific process can be summarized as that in time t, Agent i calculates the integrated reward R t i , j based on the dynamic environment and the current load state S t i , j . And the action A t i , j can be decided through the network. Finally, decisions A t i , j are executed by the smart meter for energy management. At the same time, Agent i updates its network and moves to the next interval t + 1 through the state transition equation shown in (2) (4) (6) (8). The key processes such as decision making and network optimization are described in the following two sections. (2) Decision making The decision-making process is Agent i decides the action A t i , j through the ε - greddy policy and decision-making network Q i . This process is expressed by (35) [30]. (35) A t + 1 i , j = Random action , P = ε arg max Q i S t i , j , A t i , j , P = 1 - ε where P = ε means the Agent has a probability of ε to take the random action; Similarly, P = ε means the Agent has a probability of 1 - ε to take action the maximum reward, 0 < ε < 1 ； Q i is the network that Agent i uses for decision making. It can be defined by the Bellman Equation as Eq. (36) [31]. (36) Q i S t i , j , A t i , j = ( 1 - β ) Q i S t i , j , A t i , j + β R i S t i , j , A t i , j + γ max Q i S t + 1 i , j , A i where Q i S t i , j , A t i , j is the output of the network under the action, state of jth load i at time t; R i S t i , j , A t i , j is the comprehensive cost under the action, state of jth load i at time t. it is also the opposite of the objective function, - f t . max Q i S t + 1 i , j , A i is the network maximum output that can be obtained by taking all possible actions in the action space Ai at the next moment t + 1; “=” represents the assignment process in the iteration for updating the network Qi , instead of representing the equivalence relation. β and γ are the learning factor and discount factor. It lies between 0 and 1, respectively. They characterize the update efficiency of the network. (3) Network optimization The structure of the network training optimization relationship is shown in Fig. 3 . The labeled data required for the network training process is constructed by (36). To avoid the correlation and non-stationary distribution of datasets, we construct the memory pool as well as the experience replay mechanism. Meanwhile, since the data used for training are updated in real-time, this will cause network fluctuations. For this reason, in the optimization structure, the main network is required to generate the current output. And another target network is used to generate the target value. It is used to train the main network. By replicating the main network to the target network in a fixed step, the network fluctuations are mitigated with the proposed freeze parameter mechanism. 4 Case study 4.1 Simulation parameters Dynamic optimal management is adopted for the HEMS at fifteen-minute intervals. To consider the nighttime charging/discharging continuity of electric vehicles, we take 10:00 to 10:00 of the next day as a cycle for management. And we denote it as 10:00 to 34:00 [32]. The price and energy data used to train and test this model were obtained from the PJM [33]. Specifically, the data from June 1, 2021, to June 30, 2021, were used to train the model. We set the capacity of the memory pool to 4000. The replay units are set to 500. The exploration rate is 0.1. The discount factor is 0.9. The learning factor is 0.1. The exploration factor is between 1 and 0. The target network is updated every 20 steps. And the number of exploration steps is 20,000. As for the input and output dimensions of the Agent i decision network Qi , they are determined by the state action space of each type of load. The number of neurons in the hidden layer is selected as 400, 100, and 100, respectively. And three non-shiftable loads are considered, as well as time-shiftable loads represented by washing machine dishwasher, power-shiftable loads of two air conditioners with different working hours, and a battery storage device and an electric vehicle. The proposed HEMS, represented by the above typical loads, can be extended to more loads. The parameters of are shown in Table 1 . It should be pointed out that the proposed energy management strategy is model-free. The typical scenarios such as PV, load demand, and price are unknown before the management. Through “dynamic acquisition, dynamic decision” mechanisms, the proposed model achieves real-time energy management. 4.2 Training process Taking Agent es as an example, the model is trained for 4000 epochs to learn the optimal energy storage load charging/discharging management at a certain time t. The evolution of the reward and cost over 4000 epochs is illustrated in Fig. 4 . It shows that under the ε - greddy policy, the action is randomly selected from the space in the first 1000 epochs. Based on the previous exploration, the Agent es is able to converge quickly and stabilize at the optimal solution around the 3800th epoch. At the same time, the energy consumption cost and carbon trading cost of the energy storage loads at the specific time t is stabilized to the lowest. 4.3 Energy management results During the above iteration, when the Agents’ output reaches its maximum and stabilizes, the energy management results of the current moment can be obtained. The results for a complete cycle are shown in Fig. 5 . The yellow shading is the period when the user is at home. Fig. 5(a) shows the load operation when the HEMS is not involved in energy management. Each load is executed according to the initial setting of the user without the demand response. Loads operate at rated power in the established interval and the battery storage device does not operate. With the inclusion of the time of use price scenario, the loads are optimized by the Agent to reduce the load from the peak price and shift to a lower price through dynamic optimal management. The specific results are shown in Fig. 5(b). Specifically, time-shiftable loads are scheduled to operate during off-peak price or PV output sufficiency hours. They reduce power at a high price and increase operating power at a low price. For example, the time of use price is higher from 14:00 to 18:00, and the actual power is 60 % of the rated power. The time of use price in 26:00 ∼ 29:00 is lower, and the power-shiftable loads operate with full power at this period to meet the uses’ comfort demand. Under the management of Agent es , the electric vehicle is not charging with rated power until the maximum state of charge as soon as it arrives. Through the strategy of “low charging and high discharging”, the electric vehicle can transfer the electricity between different price zones, so as to realize profits, like 21:00 ∼ 27:00. In 27:00 ∼ 29:00, the price does not fluctuate much. For the reason of charging loss, the Agent es chooses not to operate and keep the charge state. For battery storage devices, in addition to profiting from low charge and high discharge, it also charges during peak PV periods. This process can improve the PV consumption rate. And it can also smooth the system load and reduce load fluctuations. Fig. 6 shows the change in energy consumption cost, carbon trading cost, and satisfaction penalties before and after energy management. It can be seen that the energy consumption cost before energy management reaches 663.8￠, the carbon trading cost is 84.8￠, and the satisfaction penalties is 3257.3￠. After energy management, energy consumption cost, carbon trading cost, and satisfaction penalties are reduced by 39.6 %, 36.7 %, and 50.2 % respectively. Other indicators are shown in Table 2 . The PV consumption rate has increased significantly. This is achieved by management of energy storage. Due to frequent switching, the load fluctuation has increased, which is still within an acceptable range. Under the guidance of the time of use price as well as the ladder-type carbon price, the energy consumption cost and carbon trading cost are significantly reduced. Under energy storage management, the PV utilization during the valley is improved, and the consumption rate is significantly increased. At the same time, load fluctuations are smoothed. 4.4 Performance comparison In this section, to further verify the decision-making capability of the proposed algorithm, five different energy management cases are presented for comparison. Case 1 is our proposed DQN based dynamic optimal strategy. In case 2, we evaluate the optimization problems with dynamic programming under an ideal situation where the prices are all known in advance. In case 3, loads orderly participate HEMS. Time-shiftable loads, and power-shiftable loads are not sensitive to the price. They operate with rated power during preset hours. The electric vehicle is charging immediately with the maximum charging rate when the electric vehicle arrives home. In case 4, under the model predictive control frame, a long short-term memory network is used to provide the dynamic forecasting price over a rolling horizon of 5 h. And dynamic programming is presented to solve the optimization problems in MPC. Similarly, for case 5, support vector regression is used to forecast. The model predictive control frame and optimization model in case 5 are the same as case 4. The 20 test days are used for performance comparison. The load demand for 20 cycles is randomly generated according to Table 1. And the environmental and load data in one cycle of different cases are uniform and known. Price information is taken from June 10, 2021, to June 30, 2021. The cumulative costs of different cases over the test days are presented in Fig. 7 . We can observe that due to the absence of optimal management, case 3 has the highest daily comprehensive cost as well as the highest cumulative comprehensive cost. It is much higher than in other cases. Case 2 uses real data for global optimization. The comprehensive cost of case 2 is the lowest among all cases. It is the ideal result. Analyzing and comparing the two rolling optimization cases 4 and case 5, we are able to find that the difference mainly comes from the accuracy of the forecasting model. Our proposed strategy in case 1 is better than case 4 and case 5, second only to the ideal state. Furthermore, we do not need a forecasting model before optimization. 5 Discussion on hyperparameter The trade-off between energy consumption-carbon emissions cost and comfort varies from user to user. This is reflected in the variation of hyperparameter, like the satisfaction penalty factors α i . For this purpose, we investigate the situation of various loads with different hyperparameters. For time-shiftable loads, the distribution of the start-up time is studied with five different α ts from 0 to 1. Fig. 8 shows that the time-shiftable load does not operate when α ts < 0.01. Therefore, it is not shown in Fig. 9 . Since the α ts is set too small, the satisfaction penalty can be negligible for the energy consumption-carbon emissions cost. Therefore, the Agent ts chooses not to turn it on for cost reasons. When α ts = 1, the penalty factor is too large, causing the time-shiftable load to turn on at the beginning of the cycle. When the coefficient is between the two, the most favorable decision can be made based on the coefficient and time of use price. For example, α ts =0.2 turn-ons later than α ts = 0.5, but the price is lower. At the price shown in Fig. 8, the time-shiftable load does not turn on after 24:00, since the lowest price occurs at 24:00. Similarly, for power-shiftable loads, energy management results with different α ps are shown in Fig. 9. It can be seen that the mean power of power-shiftable load increases continuously with increasing coefficients α ps . The different coefficients suggest the implication of cost expenditure and satisfaction penalty. The different coefficients show the implication of the energy consumption-carbon emissions cost and comfort penalty. The larger the coefficient, the more user prefers the comfort of the environment. At the same time, the power is also adjusted with the time of use price under a specific factor. Agent ps will reduce the power-shiftable load power during the peak hours, and tend to increase the power during the low hours in pursuit of comfort. For example, around 15:00 and 30:00, the price is relatively at the peak. So the load is reduced. While at 27:00, the price is relatively low and the load power is increased to operate at a relatively rated power. As for the electric vehicle, the results are shown in Fig. 10 . The result of the changing power is similar to the power-shiftable loads. Large α es will lead to the situation in case 3, while too small will result in no action. In addition, electric vehicles will discharge at peak prices. By converting and storing valley-price electricity to supply the demand during peak hours. Thus, the benefits of energy storage can be realized while satisfying the demand of HEMS. For example, at 19:00, the price is relatively high, and the state of charge decreases when 2 < α es < 3, that is, the V2G phenomenon occurs. In addition, we analyze the distribution of energy consumption-carbon emissions cost and satisfaction penalties when α es changes from 2.8 to 3.3, with a step size of 0.02. The results are shown in Fig. 11 . Combined with the analysis of Fig. 10 and Fig. 11, it can be seen that when the penalty coefficient is larger, the user's satisfaction demand is higher. And the electric vehicle state of charge needs to meet the expected value as soon as possible. It leads to a higher energy consumption-carbon emissions cost. When the penalty coefficient decreases, the charging/discharging switching is gradually frequent. And the expected value of the charge state is reached later due to the existence of delayed charging (no action) or discharging, the expected state is reached later. As a result, the user satisfaction penalty increases. But the cost of user fees is significantly lower. Therefore, the different satisfaction penalty coefficients reflect the trade-offs between the user's interests for time and cost. The various coefficients available to users are important to meet their different demand preferences. 5.1 Robustness assessment In order to consider the performance of HEMS under uncertain environmental scenarios and different user needs, this paper evaluates the generalization ability and robustness of the model from the load level and the individual level. In the load layer, in this paper, under the random electricity price scenario for 5 consecutive days, the energy management is carried out on the load charging and discharging of electric vehicles with different discharge depths and differentiated travel demands. The results are shown in Fig. 12 . In Fig. 12(a), the curve shows the time of use price for five consecutive days from June 4, 2021, to June 8, 2021. The period when electric vehicle stays at home is illustrated with grey shading. The electric vehicle is mainly managed during this period. The real-time power of the electric vehicle is represented by the yellow bar. It shows a high correlation between charging/discharging power and time of use price trends. One can observe that the Agent es choose to charge when the electricity price is on the valley and to discharge when the price is at the peak. In particular, the Agent es choice not to manage electric vehicles for charging/discharging at certain times when the price does not fluctuate much. This does not mean that it is insensitive to electricity prices. On the contrary, Agent es choose to maintain the state accordingly. Because the penalties and costs associated with the action are sometimes too high compared with the profit, like the time during the midway of the third management cycle, and the end of the fourth. The daily state of charge of an electric vehicle and energy consumption-carbon trading union cost are presented in Fig. 12(b). After energy management, the state of charge is close to the upper limit when it leaves home. This indicates that the electric vehicle is well charged. And the charging/discharging results meet the basic travel needs of the user. At the individual level, the robustness is verified by four users with different satisfaction penalty coefficients based on their individual behavioral habits and demand. 500 scenarios are sampled from the 70,000 scenarios formed according to Table 1. The cost distribution of each user under 500 scenarios for different users is shown in Fig. 13 . For different users, the comprehensive cost distribution under each scenario distribution is stable within a certain range. It indicates that the method is relatively stable in decision results for different environmental scenarios and random initial conditions. Therefore, it has good robustness without deviating or crashing in the training and optimization process. 6 Conclusions This paper proposed a model-free dynamic optimal strategy for low-carbon HEMS. As there is no demand for any forecast information or distribution knowledge of HEMS, the proposed dynamic strategy is model-free. Eventually, the dynamic optimal management strategy is solved by the DQN algorithm with the aim of minimizing the energy consumption cost, carbon trading cost, and user satisfaction penalties. Simulation results show that: 1) The model takes into account the energy economy, low-carbon operation, and user satisfaction of the HEMS. Compared with the day-ahead forecasting-based management model, the proposed strategy is more feasible. Based on the basic needs of users, it can ensure the low-carbon economic operation of the system. 2) The management strategy can be dynamically optimized and adaptive to stochastic environments. At the same time, through the adjustment of parameters, the model can provide users with a variety of feasible energy management strategies with different preferences for users to choose from, which is of great significance to meet the respective scheduling needs of different users. 3) The proposed energy management strategy does not depend on the probability distribution and prediction information of the system data. It has good performance in convergence ability and stability under the non-prediction mechanism, and the model has certain robustness. It should be pointed out that this study only addresses the interaction between the demand-side and the power system from the perspective of individual users. It has not yet considered the user groups and their impact on the power system. Therefore, further studies will focus on the joint dispatch from the perspective of aggregators or microgrids. coredata.dc:description: This paper presents a model-free dynamic optimal management strategy for a low-carbon home energy management system (HEMS) based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL). The method can ideally handle the uncertainties and dynamics of renewable energy and demand-side load. Firstly, the load model is established by a deep Q network (DQN) algorithm with the advantage of ignoring traditional forecasting steps on stochastic environments such as renewable energy generation, load demand, price, etc. Then multi-agents are established for dynamic management based on the DRL. Through “dynamic acquisition, dynamic decision” mechanism, the proposed model-free strategy achieves real-time energy management that can adaptively respond to stochastic environments. Secondly, considering the constraints of system carbon emissions and carbon trading, the proposed strategy can minimize the energy consumption cost, carbon trading cost, and user satisfaction penalties. Ultimately, the effectiveness of the proposed strategy is verified through case studies. Experimental results demonstrate that the strategy can significantly reduce the overall cost, including a 36.7% reduction in carbon trading. At the same time, user satisfaction penalties are reduced by 50.2%. Further, the agent hyperparameter could also be adjusted to capture the trade-off between cost savings and satisfaction penalties. And compared with the traditional forecast-based management strategy, it overcomes the problem of uncertainties and avoids forecasting errors to better accommodate the stochastic environment.
coredata.dc:title: Model-free dynamic management strategy for low-carbon home energy based on deep reinforcement learning accommodating stochastic environments
